content.description:
One of the best routes at the Aretes, an unsung classic. Gently overhanging and endurancy with a couple of cruxes.

Climb through moderate terrain for the first 5 bolts, clipping the Open Season anchors. Pull a small bulge and continue up through juggy holds to another overlap, where Whiplash really begins. Clip the bolt above the overlap from an undercling, move left, and make a big throw or high step to a rounded jug for the first crux. Move right around the bolt, then back left into a decent right-hand undercling/sidepull pocket for the second crux. Mostly positive pockets and rails from here, as long as you can fight the pump!
content.location: Halfway up the lower Shooting Gallery gully.  Look for 2 bolts that head slightly right to a hand crack.

content.description: Technical face and arete, with a desperate stab to a pocket/sidepull at the crux.  Don't blow the moves getting to the next bolt.  A little hard to decipher if it hasn't seen much traffic lately, which it probably hasn't.  Worthy of more attention.
content.protection: 7 bolts. Shares lower-off anchors with Visions of Impalement.
content.location: Furthest right route on the Lower Shooting Gallery.  Belay from ledge approximately 30' off the ground.

content.description:
This route is fantastic and deserves more attention. Similar to its neighbor, Whiplash, but with a crux that is both more sustained and higher intensity. Travels through a beautiful bulge of smooth blank limestone that appears to have had giant lemon wedge chunks sliced out of it creating intricate, macro features that one cannot simply downpull.

Start on a pleasant slab and reach a good rest before a small roof pull. Once transitioned onto the vertical face, it is on for the next several bolts. Negotiate small pockets, slopey crimps, and smeary feet while fighting the quickly encroaching pump. A couple of tension-y sequences through undercling crimps above your head will test your worthiness and add to the fatigue. A good undercling is your only respite before the crux sequence, an off-camber power move requiring subtle body english. The bump into the largest lemon wedge is only about 6-inches, but is the hardest move you will pull today. After this, a jug rest and the route joins Bambi Slayer next door. 5.10 has never felt so pumpy.
content.protection: 17 Bolts. Gear down low in the easier section is optional. Long slings are nice for down low and for the last couple bolts. The rope drag/weight is real.
content.location: In the scary gully, just left of Whiplash.

climbs.name: Open Season
climbs.fa: Paul Humphrey, Cedar Wright, Eric Chemello

content.description: Thin face to a cruiser hand crack. Decent route on its own, but mostly a way to access Whiplash.
content.location: Halfway up the lower Shooting Gallery gully.  Look for 2 bolts that head right into a hand crack.

climbs.name: Mob Rules
climbs.fa: Eric Chemello. Direct start: Dru McCasland

content.description: This used to be a mixed route with a slab crux protected by a micro-cam in a flake. Now retrobolted and safe! Dru also added a very worthy direct start. The endless 11c upper headwall is unbelievable. Just like Whiplash, but easier.
content.location: One right of Blew It Crack on the ledge.

content.description: Undercover classic hiding in plain sight. It links Blew It with Mob Rules using the large slash. After the runnout 5.8 traverse you get to enjoy the incredible upper headwall of Mob Rules, while skipping its 5.12a crux. The headwall is super similar to Whiplash, just easier. Perfect finger scoops and crimps for days. Absolutely dreamy climbing. Mob It. It Rules.
content.protection: 16 bolts? Use a few slings before and after the traverse.
content.location: Climb Blew It, then traverse the slash right into Mob Rules.

content.description: Low crux, roughly at the third or fourth bolt on small crimps and sidepulls. Pull an airy roof about halfway up then killer steep climbing to the anchors on pockets and big edges.
content.location: Starts off the same ledge/belay as Smack Daddy.
